Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Inside Autocracy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although autocracies constitute forty percent of the world's regimes, social scientists lack a sophisticated account of political competition within those regimes. This project goes "inside autocracy" in the Republic of Congo to answer three questions. Under what conditions do senior military and ministry elites attempt coups d'état or struggle for greater spoils from the autocrat? What forms do these struggles take? And how do autocrats adjust survival strategies in order to maintain a stable coalition despite declining population welfare?

Since these questions require unusual access to political elites, the project focuses on one contemporary autocracy: Congo, ruled by Denis Sassou-Nguesso for all but five years since 1979. Despite the appearance of stability, political competition among the military and ministerial elite is intense and varied. Since Sassou-Nguesso's return to power after the 1997 civil war, elites have sought to demonstrate their political relevance to the government. Disgruntled military leaders occasionally foster violent conflict in the countryside; frustrated civilian leaders mobilize dissidents. Elite competition was even more violent during Sassou-Nguesso's first reign, between 1979 and 1992, when he was the frequent target of coup d?état attempts.

Survival in the midst of this competition seems to require political genius. To prevent elite conspiracies, Sassou-Nguesso employs a range of survival strategies designed to recruit elites into the coalition, induce their compliance with his orders, and then monitor their activities. He encumbers some elites in marriage networks, forces others to join secret societies, subjects some to a parallel government, and prefers everyone to live in close geographic proximity. These survival strategies, historians find, are common in autocracies. Yet contemporary political science does little to illuminate these dynamics. Political scientists generally believe autocrats create legislatures or political parties to enable commitments with their elite, moderating incentives for coups d?état. In fact, autocrats typically inherit political institutions upon claiming power.

To understand elite challenge and autocratic durability, this project builds models in which Sassou-Nguesso inherits formal and informal political institutions: the party and electoral system, and a set of military and financial elites. These institutions determine the survival strategies available to the autocrat. The project's models then explain how Sassou-Nguesso varies survival strategies across elites to maintain a stable coalition. The research substantiates this theoretical account with quantitative and qualitative methods. The empirical centerpiece is a dataset on 1,300 Congolese elites since 1970.

The project makes broader contributions as well. By probing the sources of autocrats' longevity in power, the project enhances understanding of the prospects for democratization. Findings will be of interest to journalists, the foreign aid community, and non-governmental organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Autocrats preside over 40% of the world’s governments; their citizens suffer lower standards of living and more civil war. Yet social scientists know relatively little about how autocrats consolidate personal authority (Tullock 1987; Acemoglu et al. 2003). Since the vast majority of autocrats are removed by regime insiders (Svolik 2007), my dissertation takes readers ”inside autocracy” in the Republic of Congo to answer two questions. How do autocrats neutralize rival elites, even in the face of secular declines in population welfare? And how do the coalition management strategies autocrats employ vary across elites and the political institutions – the parties, electoral systems, and strength of surrounding elites – they inherit?

My dissertation’s central argument is that autocrats construct durable coalitions by preventing elite coordination. Indeed, the vast majority of autocrats are removed by elites themselves, who possess the funding and weapons to sustain revolt. Yet although autocrats are easily deposed – one elite detains the autocrat, another seizes the airport and media outlets, and another controls the treasury – the preparatory period is fraught with risk. For an aspiring conspirator must first find co-conspirators, which requires exposing himself to potential autocratic loyalists. The autocrat’s central challenge, then, is to fashion an environment in which elites are loyal because they believe their counterparts will denounce noncompliance. Since elite beliefs are unobserved, I employ this “coordination theory of autocratic politics” to generate testable hypotheses about elite- and autocrat-level variation of each phase of the coalition management process: recruitment strategies, appointments to parallel government apparatuses, formation of compulsory elite social clubs, costly electoral alliances with the opposition parties despite easy recourse to fraud, regional security infrastructure, and determinants of elite shuffling and tenure. 

The analysis tentatively suggests two equilibria of autocratic politics. In the traditional “divide and rule” equilibrium, the ratio of an autocrats resources to his elite population is relatively small. The autocrat recruits a geographically heterogenous elite and shuffles them frequently; his hold on power is weaker and he oversees a less efficient state apparatus. In the second equilibrium, an autocrat is rich relative to the size of his elite population, enabling him to spend more freely. He can create common knowledge among elite about their privileged economic welfare, rendering conspiracies unlikely. He can afford to duplicate government portfolios, fostering elite competition and compliance. These two accountability devices enable the autocrat to forgo elite shuffling for more predictable tenure decisions, thus rewarding elite competence. More secure, the autocrat can force alliances with the opposition – undermining their credibility and reducing their future electoral threat – and force local barons compete with each other to out-mobilize the population on his behalf. 

The dissertation’s analytical and empirical approaches represent major departures from the emerging consensus among students of autocratic politics.
